title: 113_s1899
content: Consumer Renewable Credit is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a business credit for renewable energy. Consumer Renewable Credit is a new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 that offers a business credit for renewable energy based on the renewable portfolio factor and the amount of renewable electricity purchased or sold by an eligible taxpayer. The Renewable Electricity Percentage determines the Renewable Portfolio Factor for business credits under the Consumer Renewable Credit section of the Internal Revenue Code. The factor ranges from zero to 0.6 cents based on the percentage of renewable electricity purchased or sold. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to renewable electricity for eligible taxpayers, including the definition of eligible taxpayer, renewable electricity, and renewable electricity percentage. These definitions are crucial for understanding the Renewable Portfolio Factor for business credits under the Consumer Renewable Credit section of the Internal Revenue Code. The curr_chunk discusses rules for applying credits to renewable electricity purchases from eligible entities, coordination with payments, and enhancements for Native American wind and solar energy facilities located on Indian reservations. The rules for applying credits to renewable electricity purchases from eligible entities include enhancements for Native American wind and solar energy facilities located on Indian reservations. Claim for consumer renewable credit payments can be filed if at least $750 is payable for electricity purchased or produced in a quarter or prior quarters within the taxable year. Charges for integration costs do not include certain defined expenses for interconnection facilities, distribution upgrades, and network upgrades. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission allows special generating and transmitting entities to receive payment based on the amount of renewable electricity transmitted, regardless of retail sales. Special generating and transmitting entities are defined as those primarily engaged in marketing electricity and providing transmission services for over 4,000 megawatts of renewable energy. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission allows special generating and transmitting entities to receive payment based on the amount of renewable electricity transmitted, regardless of retail sales. These entities must have over 4,000 megawatts of renewable electricity generating facilities and transmit the majority of this electricity to customers outside of their region. The amendments made by this section apply to electricity produced or purchased and sold between December 31, 2013, and January 1, 2019. Additionally, there is a delay in the application of worldwide interest, with the effective date of the amendments being the date of the enactment of this Act.
